column2: The myths of the Dark Continent intrigue me.
The Inna's Apotheosis

The Inna, the mother of us all, for long has being reduced to the role of a mere subject or adviser of powerful rulers.
But those dark days are over today. All the great Magadjas have met today in the court of [From.GetTitledName] and have invoked the bori spirits to elevate [Root.RelHead.GetTitledName] to a divine character.

The Inna, possessed by the spirit of Magiro, the oldest and wisest of the bori, has received the authority to decide on all the spiritual issues that concern the faithful. The drums and marimbas rumble through the streets while the great mother is carried by her parishioners to the Kano temple, from where she will now rule the city until the end of time.
Glory to our mother, [Root.RelHead.GetBestName]!

To all my faithful,\nFor long the unbelievers have lived in our lands, shared our tables and enjoyed the protection of our spears. This is an example of the infinite tolerance of our faith. However it’s time for these fools who reject the truth of the Jan Gari to repay our generosity. For this reason I authorize the lords to tax their unfaithful peasantry.\nLovingly, your Inna
The Inna's word bring joy to my soul… and my pocket.

The Tan Garki are the children of the shield, the warrior spirits summoned by all of the great fighters of the central Sahel.
Recently a group of devout soldiers has organized a meeting in the old city of Kano, at the great ceremony presided over by the Inna herself, the soldiers were possessed by the boris of war and took an oath to defend the faith by any means necessary.

The group of warrior devotees calls themselves the "Living Tan Garki" and are willing to fight for any ruler who marches his armies in the name of the Inna.
The spirits themselves will now fight on our side!
Possessed warriors? A most curious thing.
These infidels are possessed by demons!

The tyeddo are a caste of West African warriors, sometimes considered to be slave warriors. Recently the many communities of the A Tat Roog faith have pooled their resources together to assemble a new tyeddo army that would not be loyal to any particular king, but to the faith itself.\n\nThese Sacred Tyeddo soldiers will dedicate their lives to protect any devout of Roog and will guide their swords not by the command of monarchs, but by the Yoonir star.
These faithful are slaves to Roog and no one else.
Noble slaves, but still slaves.
A slave army? Pitiful.

In 703 the great Queen Dihya, last of the faithful Amazigh monarchs, was stripped of her rightful title by the invading Arab usurpers. For generations the remnants of their army and its descendants have wandered the Sahara selling their sweat and blood as mercenaries, dishonoring their heritage like vulgar sellswords.\n\nHowever, today everything changed. The new commander of the band has made an oath to only fight in the name of the true faith, and only pledge his spear to those marching in the name of Tanit. Generations after the fall of Numidia, its orphans will fight only for the Amazigh faithful.
With their aid, North Africa shall be free once more.
An old and proud group, if ever there was one.
Just the remains of a defeated pagan army.

It seems that my interest in the the legends of the Sudan has come to the attention of one of their practitioners within the realm. We met and have had the most fruitful discussions about theology and other matters.
The African Holy Wars

In response to the endless aggression of the Abrahamic invaders, the Great [Root.GetTitledName] has made a call to all true believers of the Sudan to take arms in defense of the old gods. All reformed religious leaders in the southern continent have answered the call and will now be ready to launch Great Holy Wars. This seems to be the beginning of a new era of military conquest for the Sudanese gods’ most faithful.
They will come to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName] by reason or by force.
A new dawn comes to the faithful.
Horrors from the Dark Continent!
Find a Way, or Make One

In ancient times when Dido reigned in her city of gold and spices, when Hannibal and Hasdrubal commanded the armies of Numidia in European lands, when the Berber ruled the earth and the Phoenician the sea, there was a dream named Carthage. A dream that ended when the Italian eagle divided our people and plundered our lands, covering our hopes with salt.\n\nToday the Phoenicians are only a memory, but we children of Numidia are still here, and we still venerate the great goddess Tanit. And with great effort we have managed to restore her empire, to once again make ours all that the sea and the desert touch.
For us, there is no spring. Just the wind that smells fresh before the storm.
Reborn From the Ashes and Salt

Something that seemed impossible has happened.  In the lands of North Africa the Amazigh leader [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has made an important proclamation: the ancient Carthaginian Empire has been reborn from its ashes.\n\nThrough the streets of the old city of Carthage the marabouts dance singing chants in honor of the old Punic-Berber goddess Tanit, and all the pagans of North Africa make toasts in honor of the new emperor. Only time will tell if this new empire will achieve supremacy in the Mediterranean Sea or if it will perish like its predecessor.

One would believe that killing one hundred thousand men and salting their land would be enough for them to learn their lesson, but still, here we are. The pagan and grotesque [From.GetDynName], a worshiper of the demonic Punic goddess, has proclaimed the creation of a new Carthaginian Empire. This affront is certainly not something I can ignore as the head of the true Roman Empire.\n\nRome has defeated Carthage three times on the battlefield, and we are not afraid to do it a fourth time.
They know how to gain a victory, but do they know how to make use of it?
Carthago delenda est!

To the [GetFromRootInsult] [Root.GetDynName], I have heard from a good source that now you pretend that your African dominions are a Carthaginian Empire reborn. If so, I can assure you that in my position as ruler of the true Roman Empire I will follow in the footsteps of the good Scipio and salt your lands once more.\nYour's truly\n[From.GetTitledName]

To the [GetFromRootInsult] [Root.GetDynName], what was it that Cato the Elder used to say? Carthago delenda est? If you want to revive an empire that only deserves the grave then you will have to face the full force of the civilized world. If you want to save yourself some humiliation maybe you should salt your own land before I get the chance.\nBest wishes, [From.GetTitledName]

To the [GetFromRootInsult] [Root.GetDynName], when my messengers gave me the news, I almost died of laughter. It seems you have committed the foolishness of resurrecting an empire that should have been confined to the history books.
It does not matter, as Emperor of the Romans and successor of Aeneas I will take care of plowing your armies as Aeneas plowed your predecessor.
From Rome with love,
[From.GetTitledName]
Fourth time's the charm.
You will cry: Hannibal at the Gates!
Sulla potuit, ego non potero?

A wicked soul known as [From.GetDynName] has been proclaimed [From.GetTitledNameWithNick]. And just like that a new pretender to the corpse of our old enemy, Rome, has been brought into the world. We all know the tale of the noble queen Dido whose heart was broken by the lecherous Aeneas, making the queen proclaim eternal hate between the men of Rome and Carthage. Today it is me who sits on the throne of Dido, and for that reason alone the sacred oath made in the name of the goddess Tanit cannot be ignored.\n\nMany will say that [From.GetDynName] is no true Roman and that the new realm is in no way the Roman Empire. But I know in my heart of hearts that I will think of [From.GetHerHim] as Roman when I put my sword through [From.GetHerHis] heart.
We are destined to do this forever.

To the Roman pretender [Root.GetDynName], the news has reached my ears that you have taken the crown of the empire of the Romans. Many will say that you are not a true Roman, but I give you my word that I believe you a true Scipio Africanus. I'll have that in mind when I put your neck under my axe and cover your lands with salt.\nYour's truly,\n[From.GetTitledName]
Carthago delenda est!
You are currently the highest magistrate of the reborn Carthaginian Empire. May your reign be a prosperous one!
Omek tannou!
You are no longer the ruler of the Carthaginian Empire. It will surely crumble without your guiding hand to lead it.
You are no longer the ruler of the Carthaginian Empire. It turns out you know how to gain a victory, but you do not know how to make use of it.
Carthage is lost without me!
Furthermore, Carthage has been destroyed.
Rome Burns!

In an act of bloody revenge for the destruction of Carthage centuries ago, [Root.GetTitledNameWithNick] has ordered the destruction of the eternal city. The Amazigh soldiers loot everything they can carry while they lock the local priests in their temples and set them on fire.\n\n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] [Root.GetHerselfHimself] now parades through the burning Rome, in a chariot pulled by two elephants, throwing salt into the streets, in mockery of what in ancient times was the ceremony of the Roman Triumph. This abominable act will certainly not only damage the reputation of the city, as its perpetrator claims, but of the Catholic faith.
A toast to old Hannibal!

In an act of bloody revenge for the destruction of Carthage centuries ago, [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has ordered the destruction of the eternal city. The Amazigh soldiers loot everything they can carry while they lock the local priests in their temples and set them on fire.\n\n[From.GetTitledFirstName] [From.GetHerselfHimself] now parades through the burning Rome, in a chariot pulled by two elephants, throwing salt into the streets, in mockery of what in ancient times was the ceremony of the Roman Triumph. This abominable act will certainly not only damage the reputation of the city, as its perpetrator claims, but of the Catholic faith.
When Rome falls, the world shall fall!
The Fall of the Second Rome

Centuries ago the first Rome enslaved the innocent of the first Carthage and salted the land, but today the second Carthage is taking its revenge on the second Rome. [Root.GetTitledNameWithNick] has unleashed a furious army into what was once called the city of the world's desire.\n\nThe Nova Roma of Constantinus and his “carpenter god”, as the invading Amazigh call it, is now covered in the blood of those who resisted the attacking soldiers. All the local priests were taken to the Hagia Sophia and, according to those who witnessed the horror, sacrificed in the name of some North African goddess. This day will be marked forever in the history books as the great Carthaginian revenge.
See the glyph of Tanit, in this sign we will conquer!

Centuries ago the first Rome enslaved the innocent of the first Carthage and salted the land, but today the second Carthage is taking its revenge on the second Rome. [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has unleashed a furious army into what was once called the city of the world's desire.\n\nThe Nova Roma of Constantinus and his “carpenter god”, as the invading Amazigh call it, is now covered in the blood of those who resisted the attacking soldiers. All the local priests were taken to the Hagia Sophia and, according to those who witnessed the horror, sacrificed in the name of some North African goddess. This day will be marked forever in the history books as the great Carthaginian revenge.
Is the ghost of Odoacer haunting the world?
Once More, With Feeling

The old Carthage was built, destroyed and rebuilt. It seems that its African gods have doomed it to repeat this process forever. The armies of [Root.GetDynName], who goes by the title of [Root.GetTitledNameWithNick] and claims to be the successor of the old Rome, are now reenacting what Scipio did so many centuries ago when he burned the city to the ground and salted the land.\n\nThe self-proclaimed Roman soldiers now march through streets of the Carthaginian capital, using the sword on those who resist and the chain on those who don’t. The African temples have being defaced, the idols smashed and the marabouts are now corpses or slaves. Somewhere, in this world or the next, the ghost of Hannibal cries bitter tears for a second time, as Scipio mocks him.
Roma invicta est!

The old Carthage was built, destroyed and rebuilt. It seems that its African gods have doomed it to repeat this process forever. The armies of [From.GetDynName], who goes by the title of [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] and claims to be the successor of the old Rome, are now reenacting what Scipio did so many centuries ago when he burned the city to the ground and salted the land.\n\nThe self-proclaimed Roman soldiers now march through streets of the Carthaginian capital, using the sword on those who resist and the chain on those who don’t. The African temples have being defaced, the idols smashed and the marabouts are now corpses or slaves. Somewhere, in this world or the next, the ghost of Hannibal cries bitter tears for a second time, as Scipio mocks him.
Our only crime was daring to dream with a second chance.
These Carthaginians, when will they learn?
The Old Borders are Restored

The gods have given to man no sharper spur to victory than contempt of death. The old empire, which was once stabbed in the heart and left for dead in ashes and salt, has now been restored to its full glory. Never again shall the sons of Carthage fear the crushing defeat, never again shall the mothers of Carthage see their sons taken in chains by Northerner tyrants.\n\nThe priests of Tanit celebrate across the Maghreb, for once again they are protected by the one true heir of the beloved Dido.  Merchants set sails for places yet unexplored as once Hanno did.   Gold and prosperity once again fill the metropolises of Africa. What was built with Phoenician ingenuity and Numidian blood has been rebuild by their only heirs and a forgotten nation has now a second chance in this world.
A day that will forever be remembered.

In an effort to convince the court of my piety, I have chosen to attend [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyName] and give a grand speech to my people, and to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName]. The [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] eyes me curiously as I enter the building, and I stop for moment to gather my thoughts. May [Root.TrueReligion.GetHighGodName] forgive me, but I need to impress these people and choose my words carefully.
a possession ceremony
the local temple

As I step up to the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyLocation], people eye me carefully. They depend upon me, as [Root.GetTitle] and my connection to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName], to guide them. The [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] nods encouragingly at me, and I look around to study the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyHangings]. When I finally speak, I imagine that I am praising [Root.TrueReligion.GetHighGodName] – unsurprising, my words have never seemed more true.
center of the room
altar
musicians of the possession ceremony
ornamental masks hanging from the walls
Tanit glyphs carved into the walls of the temple

As I step up to the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyLocation], people eye me warily. They depend upon me, as [Root.GetTitle] and my connection to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName], to guide them. The [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] nods solemnly at me. I look look around to study the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyHangings], silently begging [Root.TrueReligion.GetHighGodName] for some surge of inspiration – it never comes and my heart sinks. I leave the center of the ceremony leavy everybody confused.

I walk to the center of the ceremony and make a quick decision – as I reach my place, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin singing [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I sing, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, everyone seems to be holding their breath. For a moment I worry that my stunt has failed. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] exclaims "A VISION! My [Root.GetLordLady], let me help you stand!"

I step up to the altar and make a quick decision – as I reach the center of the stage, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin quoting [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I speak, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, everyone seems to be holding their breath. For a moment I worry that my stunt has failed. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] exclaims "A VISION! My [Root.GetLordLady], let me help you stand!"

I walk to the center of the ceremony and make a quick decision – as I reach a group of people, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin singing [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I sing, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, they start to whisper. For a moment I am convinced that my stunt has succeeded. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] prods at me. "Uhm, my [Root.GetLordLady]? Let's get you back onto your feet."

I step forwards and make a bold decision – as I reach a group of people, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin quoting fragments of [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I speak, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, they start to whisper. For a moment I am convinced that my stunt has succeeded. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] prods at me. "Uhm, my [Root.GetLordLady]? Let's get you back onto your feet."

Many are the religious traditions of the Western Sahel, with different names for the primordial twins, the star Sirius and even for God himself. Now I have the option to choose between one of three traditions: that of the Serer, with its complex rituals and spiritualism, that of the Dogon, masters of astronomy, or that of the Malinke, conquerors and masters of the forge.
I choose the Serer tradition.
I choose the Dogon tradition.
I choose the Malinke tradition.

The Serer practice “The way of the Divine”, the most complex faith in all of West Africa. They refer to the supreme god as Roog, the primordial twins as Yaab and Yop, and the great star Sirius as Yoonir. Their spiritual knowledge is unrivaled and is based on the three worlds: the invisible world, the terrestrial world and the nocturnal world.
This truly is the way of the Divine.
I will choose another path.

The way of the Dogon is often a mystery to the outsiders. They refer to the supreme god as Amma, the primordial twins as the Nommo, and the great star Sirius as Sigui. They are masters of astronomy, and their understanding goes beyond that of any other. This accompanies a strange cosmogony filled with androgynous beings and twin spirits.
The secrets of the stars will be revealed to me.
I will choose another path.

The Malinke are people of the conquest, warriors and rulers. They refer to the supreme god as Mangala and the primordial twins as Pemba and Faro. The Malinke are masters in the manipulation of the Nyama, the life force that unites all things. This force is used for everything from war to complex works of smithy.
A faith of iron for men of iron.
I will choose another path.
The four traditions of A Tat Roog are that of the Serer, the Dogon, and the Malinke. You have decided to choose a new way, but which one shall it be?
Never mind.

In the ethereal realm of Jan Gari, the Bori spirits exist in a transcendental state incomprehensible to the mortals. If I make special contact with one of the great bori clans and enter into communion with their king, it is possible that the spirits will grant me their blessing.
Time to chose.
Maybe another time.

While I make an effort so that my soul comes in contact with the Jan Gari plane, I face the decision of which spirit I should ask for favor. There are six major categories of spirits each with their own hierarchy and a powerful spiritual king who rules over them. Which of these spiritual courts will I pay homage to?
I consider Yan Riga, the city spirits.
I consider Babbaku, the rural spirits.
I consider Tan Garki, the warrior spirits.
I had something else in mind.
I choose the Samari, the young feminine spirits.
I choose the Yayan Zanzanna, the children of the plague.
I choose the Tan Dowa, the wild spirits.
Maybe another court has what I require.

The Yan Riga, that is, those who wear clothes, are the most civilized spirits. It is said that they live in cities and know about the wisdom of men who can read. Above them reigns the spiritual king Mallam Alhaji, the so-called father of many and the oldest of all spirits.
Begin the song of The Learned One!
The Yan Riga are not for me.

The Babbaku, that is, the black ones, are inhabitants of rural villages. Some are farmers and other hunters, but all of them enjoy the country life and know how to make use of the land. Above them reigns Mai-Ja-Ciki, the one who crawls on the floor on his stomach, who is like a snake and can not speak in human language.
Oh, Wizard of the Night, what do you say?
The Babbaku are not for me.

The Tan Garki, that is, the sons of the shield, are the great warriors among the spirits. Many brave fighters seek their protection, but the true custodians of their blessings are the generals and strategists. The head of this spiritual army is Garki Baba, the great shield, protector of those who march to the battlefield.
You followers of the chief, show me the horsemen!
The Tan Garki are not for me.

Samari, the spirits of youth but also of femininity. Interestingly they are led by Ba-Gudu, the one who does not run, who is neither female nor young. It is a court full of curious talents such as giving good or bad luck to gamblers, persuade a man to desire his brother's wife, or preventing people from falling asleep.
Let him who has two wives give one!
The Samari are not for me.

The Yayan Zanzanna, the children of the plague, are child spirits with dominion over any disease, spreading smallpox and other evils among mortals. They are led by Nana Mariyamu, the naughty little queen who likes to give headaches and irritated eyes to those who are mean to her. The whole court is playful and likes to clap for no reason, after all they are just children.
Beautiful is she with her small spots!
The Yayan Zanzanna are not for me.

The Tan Dowa are spirits of the jungle, they do not resemble any human but are nature in its purest state. They are spirits of the lion, the hyena and the elephant, but also the guard dog that protects man. Zaki the lion is the first among them, and more than king of the court it can be said that he is simply the strongest among a group of beasts without a leader.
The Lion is to be feared!
The Tan Dowa are not for me.

There are hundreds of gods worshiped among the Amazigh, many taken from the cult of Egypt, the mythology of the Greeks or our own traditions as Berber peoples. Making a small offering could earn me the favor of one of these great gods.
Time to chose.
Maybe another time.
I raise a prayer to the heavens and the earth under my feet, I imagine the holy lands of the Maghreb in all its extension and I feel a great peace. But to what god am I raising my prayers?
Tanit, the great mother.
Änti, the mighty giant.
Gurzil, the bull of war.
I had something else in mind.
Magec, lady of the sun.
Set, lord of chaos.
Maybe another deity has what I require.

Tanit is the mother goddess who brings the rains to the arid lands and gives fertility to women without children. Tanit was first worshiped among both Numidians and Phoenicians, eventually becoming the patroness of Carthage. From there, her cult spread to all the Mediterranean.
Her blessing will bring happiness and love to my family.

Änti or Antaeus was a powerful giant, born of the very earth, who became the greatest fighter in the whole world because he was invincible as long as he was touching his mother. The Greek men tell that he was defeated by Heracles, but we Amazigh know the truth - he simply returned to his mother's womb, in the Tangier, waiting for a new challenger.
With the blessing of Änti I will also be invincible.

Gurzil is the great god-bull of war. Many warriors sought his blessing on the battlefield. Ierna dedicated his life to the faith to gain strength against the Greek emperor, and Dihya bore his image when she confronted the Islamic invaders.
I raise a prayer to the great bull, bring death to my enemies.

The sun lady Magec is beautiful like no other and full of blessings even to those who do not revere her. In the old traditions the lady of the sun was kidnapped by the nefarious Guayota, who held her inside a volcano in the Guanche Islands, where men speak in whistles.
The sun that illuminates all land will let me understand it better.

Set is a god of chaos, the desert, the wild storms and of violence among men. In the ancient times when the pharaohs still ruled their river kingdom, they also though he was the god of foreigners, because he loved us Amazighs. Set is a trickster but also a protector who fights a constant battle against death itself.
Give me some of your cleverness, lord of chaos.

Our fertile lands give us life, but this is not without a price. For this reason each year a young woman is chosen to be a bride for the old snake spirit of the waters that is known as Bida. All the people of the domain must be invited for a feast to celebrate the occasion in which the blessed lady will be chosen.
Only life can pay for life.

The wandering griot entered the castle telling the story of the kings of old and did not stop until he found me. With a flourishing bow and one long, sad tone from his balafon he finished his poem and asked for my patronage.

The best part about preparing a feast is deciding what foodstuff to serve. I must purchase mutton, millet and rice, spices, yogurt and tea, honey for the desserts, cheeses and perhaps even sweet potato or baobab leaves.
If I want to impress my guests it is essential that I have the pelt of a lion on display. Who will get the prestigious task of facing against the king of beasts in the great hunt?
I will hunt the lion myself
Most of the preparations for the feast before the sacrificial ceremony have been made, now I only have to send out the invitations!

Dear [Root.GetBestName], I hereby invite you to oversee the annual sacrifice to Bida in [From.Location.GetName]. Your presence at the ceremony and feast would be greatly appreciated and I look forward to your attendance.\n\n[From.GetTitledFirstName]

Dear [Root.GetTitledFirstName], I thank you for your invitation but I will not be able to attend the ceremony. In fact, I refuse to set my foot in the same castle as you!

Respectfully,

[From.GetTitledFirstName]

Much thought and consideration had been put into the courses served at [Root.Liege.GetTitledFirstName]'s feast. The mutton was so tender it almost melted on the tongue, the chicken delicious, the palm wine was properly aged, but the dessert outdid all the other dishes: the most delicious thiacry I have ever tasted...

The courses at the feast were few but palatable. We were served mutton, some sort of fish, a few palm wines, millet and a small dessert. It was not really the abundance of food I had expected [Root.Liege.GetTitledFirstName] to serve at [Root.Liege.GetHerHis] feast.
Where's the rice?

Instead of the millet, the palm wine and all kinds of meats I had thought [Root.Liege.GetTitledFirstName] would serve at [Root.Liege.GetHerHis] feast, we were served courses that could have been served at dinner at a much poorer [Root.Liege.GetManWoman]'s table.
The griot sang and the ladies wept, the griot sang and the lords laughed. His performance at my feast was above my expectations and I congratulated myself for hiring him.
I am not ashamed to admit I both laughed and cried when the griot sang. The griot's performance at [From.GetTitledFirstName]'s feast was extraordinary!
The annual sacrifice has come to an end and the guests are now departing, satisfied with your hospitality. Watching the riverbank, you wonder if it’s all worth it.
We do as we must.
[From.GetTitledFirstName]'s ceremony presenting this year’s sacrifice to Bida is finally over. The young maiden has been sent to the serpent’s embrace. Now is time to go home and return to our lives.
The loss of a good woman, a necessary evil.
I have to cancel the Bida ceremony due to the war I am currently fighting against one of my enemies. Perhaps after the war I might throw a victory feast.

Dear [Root.GetTitledFirstName], due to the unfortunate war I have to cancel this years sacrifice. I hope you will be able to attend the victory fest I plan to have after the war.\n\n[From.GetTitledFirstName]

The snake’s bride must be selected with precision - for this reason one hundred young ladies appear before you on the back of one hundred horses. The guests of the feast must select the most beautiful among all but as host you have the final say.
Whatever plebian girl they like is fine.
One of my own court would show generosity.
My own daughter will have the honor.
I do need to empty a cell.
Can I be the sacrifice? I am pretty.

Once everyone has gone to bed in preparation for the ceremony, somebody knocks at your door. It’s the snake’s fiancée, and she is crying. She says between sobs: “My [Root.GetTitle], please, I don’t want to die. I will give you anything, my loyalty, my life, my heart.” You feel a sting in your heart seeing that beautiful face covered in tears.
This atrocity is over, you will not suffer under my watch.
The snake demands, and we must pay.
Perhaps some other girl could replace you.

A procession marches to the river in the morning and with them rides [bida_sacrifice.GetTitledName] carrying a golden spoon. Once there, the head priest attaches heavy weights to the girl’s legs and places her in a small boat. Everybody is then commanded to look away. You hear a splash as the girl is swallowed by the river. The viper of the waters has got his bride.

A procession marches to the river in the morning and with them rides the peasant girl carrying a golden spoon. Once there, the head priest attaches heavy weights to the girl’s legs and places her in a small boat. Everybody is then commanded to look away. You hear a splash as the girl is swallowed by the river. The viper of the waters has got his bride.

A procession marches to the river in the morning and you ride with them carrying a golden spoon. Once there the head priest attaches heavy weights to your legs and places you in a small boat. Everybody is then commanded to look away as the priest pushes you to the river. This is your wedding, but you don’t see the groom.
Only life can pay for life.
What? Where is the snake?

[From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has selected you as this year’s sacrifice to Bida. You are forced to parade to the river. Once there the head priest attaches heavy weights to your legs and places you in a small boat. Everybody is then commanded to look away as the priest pushes you to the river. The snake will have you as their offering.
So this is the embrace of the serpent.

Every year a young bride is sacrificed to the river, and every year you wonder if it’s all worth it.\n\nYour suspicions are gone for the time being. The snake must love his new bride, because the land is more fertile than ever and the mines keep the revenue coming.
Every year a young bride is sacrificed to the river, and every year you wonder if it’s all worth it.\n\nMaybe it’s all a charade, the mines are not producing and the rains are late this year.
We pay with life, and we get life.
Cursed snake.
This year’s intended sacrifice [bida_sacrifice.GetTitledName], has died prematurely. Without a proper sacrifice the ritual for Bida is now ruined and the event must be canceled immediately.
The snake will be displeased.
With [bida_sacrifice.GetTitledName] no longer in your dungeon, this year’s ceremony has being left without a proper sacrifice. The ritual must be postponed.
The snake will be displeased.

Our people, more than men and women, are stallions and mares. We are born on the backs of steeds and therefore we celebrate on horseback. The Hawan Sallah is a beautiful opportunity to show this. A great parade will be organized for the pleasure of nobles and commoners, so that people can see how prosperous my reign is.
What a great parade will this be!

The first thing to decide will be which horse will ride at the head of the parade. Of course it is an option to simply take one of the horses in your stables, but those old steeds will not impress anyone. Maybe it would be better to acquire a new horse for the occasion.
Whatever is in my stables will suffice.
I should buy a young mare.
A mighty stallion, nothing less.
The lion will ride a wild beast tamed by itself!

The Hawan Sallah is a great opportunity to show your riches and impress the curious. You could certainly call for the royal tailors to make you a dress of silk and gold, although perhaps it would be best to show humility among your subjects.
What's wrong with what I am wearing?
White robes are a sign of piety.
I will ride covered in gold.
I will dress in the dark mantle of those who bring the plague.
The Great Parade

All the people of [Root.Capital.GetName] congregate on both sides of the main street of the city. An army of drummers advances among them, singing songs in honor of the bori, followed by dancers who perform impressive pirouettes.\n\nAt the end of all, the main show arrives, one hundred men on beautiful steeds and at the head of them [Root.GetTitledName]. The faithful subjects cheer the name of the [Root.GetTitle] and [Root.GetSheHe] responds by greeting them with grace. The [Root.GetTitle]’s [Root.HawanSallahClothes] [Root.HawanSallahClothesEffect]. Certainly this has been a glorious day.
humble clothes have
white robes have
pompous jewelry has
unsettling black tunic has
gained everybody's approval
however been the subject of some mockery
Behold the glory of [Root.GetBestName]!

You've heard that your liege [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has organized a grand parade as part of this year's Hawan Sallah. It would certainly be worth it to join that celebration in a way that brings excitement to the occasion. Suddenly you have an idea that will make you the life and soul of the party: you are going to show up at the parade on the back of a mighty elephant.
Everybody is going to love it!
This may be the worst idea I ever had.

The parade runs without any inconvenience, or at least that's what it seems, until you hear a rumble that echoes through the streets of [Root.Capital.GetName]. Screams of terror and laughs of mockery are heard in the crowd and you can not understand what is happening.\n\nIt is then that you see the problem, it is [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] that has come to be part of the parade, not on the back of a stallion but mounted on an elephant bigger than a house. The beast makes its way through the streets while you can not help but gawk at it.
That idiot is ruining my parade!
I like this one, that’s some spunk.

On the day of the celebration you arrive at the parade on the back of a beautiful elephant, to the surprise of all. As you ride the animal you can hear the screams of the crowd, they are certainly full of excitement. For some reason [From.GetTitledFirstName] seems not to appreciate the beautiful gesture.
If [From.GetSheHe] does not appreciate Stampy then I do not appreciate [From.GetHerHim].

On the day of the celebration you arrive at the parade on the back of a beautiful elephant, to the surprise of all. As you ride the animal you can hear the screams of the crowd, they are certainly full of excitement. [From.GetTitledFirstName] seems absolutely delighted as [From.GetSheHe] approaches to pet the elephant.  This was certainly the greatest idea you've ever had.
Any friend of Stampy is a friend of mine.

You are watching the parade organized by your liege [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] for the Hawan Sallah. Everything seems in order until you see a drunkard throwing himself at the riders shouting "Ostriches are prettier than any horse!"\n\nYou have come to enjoy the parade and you will not let the imbecile ruin it, so you put him in his place with one fist. [From.GetTitledFirstName] seems impressed.
I seem to have made a new friend!

Although most of your subjects seem happy to see the parade you have organized, one of them does not seem to agree. The man, clearly drunk, stands in your way screaming that the parade would be better if we rode zebras and ostriches.\n\nJust when you think the afternoon is ruined, someone appears in the crowd and knocks out the drunk with a single blow, allowing you to continue. It's [From.GetTitledNameWithNick], who has come to your rescue.
Ha! A thousand thanks, [From.GetTitledFirstName]!

While you are riding at the head of the parade, a young man approaches you with a single red rose. He looks like a simple farmer, but he has a charming appeal, like the rose he carries with him. He also has beefy arms and an iron abdomen, it's worth mentioning.\n\nYou get off your horse and accept the rose with kindness.

While you are riding at the head of the parade, a young lass approaches you with a bouquet of wild flowers. She looks like a humble girl, but she has a unique beauty, like the flowers she carries with her. She also has generous hips and full breasts, it's worth mentioning.\n\nYou get off your horse and accept the flower bouquet with kindness.
You honor me and my faith.
Do you want to ride with me? I can sit on your lap.
Do you want to ride with me? You can sit on my lap.

The parade stretches longer than you expected, the sun shines with great force and your horse begins to look irritated. It flutters from one side to the other and annoys the other riders. Suddenly the rider at your side loses control of his horse and collides with yours. Your mount goes completely crazy, it starts jumping on its hind legs and it does not take long for you to lose your balance and fall from its back.
Here comes the ground!
I can fall on my feet!
When I selected my mount I was somewhat worried that my horse might not be enough. My concerns turned out to be baseless. The [Root.HawanSallahHorse] has impressed all the commoners.
When I selected my mount I was somewhat worried that my horse might not be enough. My concerns turned out to be correct. The [Root.HawanSallahHorse] has not been enough to impress anybody.
old barb
young mare
beautiful stallion
wild zebra that I tamed by myself
Yes, this is a fine mount.
What do they know about horsemanship?

The parade finally comes to an end, but the festivities are not over. Now is the time of the great race in which the bravest riders of [Root.Capital] will compete to decide which of them is the most skilled.\n\nOf course it would be frowned upon for someone from your high position to participate in the race, but there is no reason not to make the game more interesting. Maybe it would be a good idea to place a bet with one of the wealthy merchants of the city.
I will make a small bet.
I will take a risk.
All-in, cowardice is for poor people!
Gambling is for the wicked.

Next you must choose a horse to bet on. You could make a safe bet on the white Arabian, but the profits would be small. The palomino barb is an interesting choice, a medium risk for a medium gain. And there is the bay Andalusian, an unlikely winner, but it would make you a fortune.
Let’s play it safe with the Arabian.
I will take a risk with the barb.
The Andalusian! Why are people laughing?

At the start of the race an old soldier on the back of a black stallion quickly takes the lead. In the first three laps there seems to be no doubt who will be the champion this year. But a challenger finally manages to reduce the distance with the black steed on the last lap, it is a young ragged girl on the back of the [Root.HawanSallahBetHorse], which makes you happy because you bet on her.\n\nThe two riders fight for the front, neck to neck as the spectators shout at the edge of their seats. Finally it is the young woman on the [Root.HawanSallahBetHorse] who manages to win by a head.
white Arabian
palomino barb
bay Andalusian
What a beautiful sport this is!

At the start of the race an old soldier on the back of the [Root.HawanSallahBetHorse] quickly takes the lead, which pleases you because you bet on him. In the first three laps there seems to be no doubt who will be the champion this year. But a challenger on a black steed finally manages to reduce the distance on the last lap, it is a young ragged girl on the back of a black mare.\n\nThe two riders fight for the front, neck to neck as the spectators shout at the edge of their seats. Finally it is the young woman on the black horse who manages to win by a head.
She cheated! Unfair!

At the start of the race an old soldier on the back of a black stallion quickly takes the lead. In the first three laps there seems to be no doubt who will be the champion this year. But a challenger finally manages to reduce the distance with the black steed on the last lap, it is a young ragged girl on the back of a white mare.\n\nThe two riders fight for the front, neck to neck as the spectators shout at the edge of their seats. Finally it is the young woman on the white horse who manages to win by a head.
As long as everybody is having fun.

While the sun sets, the festivities come to an end. People return to their homes and the horses are returned to their stables. This year the Hawan Sallah was a splendid occasion and it was all thanks to you.
What a great time this was.
Sadly, the war has made it impossible to continue with the festivities. This year’s Hawan Sallah has been cancelled as a result.
Sadly, my imprisonment has made it impossible to continue with the festivities. This year’s Hawan Sallah has been cancelled as a result.
Such a shame!
The riders stop momentarily when an idiot starts running naked in front of the horses. Your companions ask you to punish the fool, but the crowd seems fond of the exhibitionist's clownery.
To the dungeon with the pervert!
Live and let live.
Several young children have gathered to watch the riders, their eyes light up seeing the brave warriors. Maybe you can cheer them up even more.
Have some coins, go and buy some sweets.
Get out of here, brats!
While the other riders take a break to perform pirouettes in front of the public, the large crowd begins to encourage you to give a speech. Of course, as [Root.GetTitle] you cannot refuse.
The glory of our armies...
Virtuous is the spirit that...
Earth will not share the rafter's envy...
The minutes pass and the riders finish with their pirouettes, but the crowd doesn't care about horses anymore, they are delighted with your words. You certainly are great with words.

The riders suddenly stop their pirouettes and indicate that it is time to continue. They are really doing you a favor. Every word you say is clumsier than the last and the crowd looks at you as if you were some kind of fool.
...and that’s the only truth!
...In conclusion, more yams?
The Hawan Sallah includes several musical performers, one of which marches right beside you playing their instruments. You wonder if they take requests.
Do you know ‘Confusion Break Bones’?
Can you play ‘Water no get enemy’?
Please play ‘Army Arrangement’.

A warehouse collapsed and the grain stored there poured out right into the main street of [Root.Capital.GetName], blocking the route. Your companions indicate you that you should get off of the horse until the warehouse owner can collect his grain.
Very well, we will wait.
Nonsense, we will march over grain if necessary.
Confiscate the grain, this mess is his fault!

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of the Samari. In their name you have promoted joy and understanding between your subjects. As a result, your diplomatic skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of Tanit. In her name you have promoted peace and understanding between your subjects. As a result, your diplomatic skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of the Tan Garki. In their name you have practiced your spear throwing and spent many hours strategizing at the war hut with your commanders. As a result, your martial skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of the Tan Dowa. In their name you have arranged a number grand hunts as well as spent many solitary hours tracking in the wilderness. As a result, your martial skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of Änti. In his name you have practiced your wrestling and spent many hours training with your commanders. As a result, your martial skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of Gurzil. In his name you have practiced your swordsmanship and spent many hours strategizing at the war table with your commanders. As a result, your martial skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of the Babbaku. In their name you have arranged harvest festivals and fertility rites, as well as spent many hours inspecting the fields of [Root.Capital.GetName]. As a result, your stewardship skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of Magec. In her name you have arranged harvest festivals and fertility rites, as well as spent many hours inspecting the fields of [Root.Capital.GetName]. As a result, your stewardship skills have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of the Yayan Zanzanna. In their name you have brewed poisons, plotted and spread disease. As a result, your skills of intrigue have been improving.
You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of Set. In his name you have plotted and spied and manipulated. As a result, your skills of intrigue have been improving.

You have toiled devoutly in your endeavor to follow the path of the Yan Riga. In their name you have sought out knowledge and purity, as well as taught and done good deeds wherever your travels have taken you. As a result, your learning has been improving.

It is early morning and you are at the shrine dedicated to the Yan Riga, deep in prayers & thought. You hear soft footsteps behind you - who could it be at this hour? [From.GetTitledFirstName], as it turns out. You exchange some pleasantries and soon you find yourself in a full-fledged conversation. You have so much in common!

Many find it odd that a [Root.GetTitle] works in the fields, but tending to the land and crops make you feel closer to the Babbaku, more so than any prayer. As you take a short break, you notice [From.GetTitledFirstName] approaching. You greet and exchange some words about the harvest. It turns out that [From.GetSheHe] is also a follower of the Babbaku!

It is a fine day and you are out hunting with a small party. As you take a break to eat your midday meal, you find yourself in a discussion on spear throwing with [From.GetTitledFirstName]. It turns out that [From.GetSheHe] is also a devout follower of the Tan Garki. The longer you talk the more you seem to have in common!

Today you have decided to dedicate the night to some gambling and celebration. As a devotee of the Samari you know well that a gambler must put his faith in the bori and it seems that [From.GetTitledFirstName] agrees. This could be the beginning of a beautiful friendship… as soon as you win the next round.

As a good ruler you decide to visit the ill being attended by the local healer. When you arrive, you see that [From.GetTitledFirstName] is already there. After some talking you realize that [From.GetSheHe] is also a devotee of the Yayan Zanzanna, which is a blessing given that you are surrounded by so much disease.

It is a fine day and you are out hunting with a small party. As you take a break to eat your midday meal, you find yourself in a discussion on tracking with [From.GetTitledFirstName]. It turns out that [From.GetSheHe] is also a devout follower of the Tan Dowa. The longer you talk the more you seem to have in common!

It is early morning and you are at the shrine dedicated to Tanit, deep in prayers. You hear soft footsteps behind you - who could it be at this hour? [From.GetTitledFirstName], as it turns out. You exchange some pleasantries and soon you find yourself in a full-fledged conversation. You have so much in common!

Today [From.GetTitledFirstName] has invited you to watch a wrestling match between two local champions, after the first round of the competition you have had time to talk and soon discovered that [From.GetSheHe] is also a devotee of Änti, the great giant fighter.

It is a fine day and you are out hunting with a small party. As you take a break to eat your midday meal, you find yourself in a discussion on archery with [From.GetTitledFirstName]. It turns out that [From.GetSheHe] is also a devout follower of Gurzil. The longer you talk the more you seem to have in common!

It is said that the nobles are pale because they spend all their time indoors, but not you. As a devotee of Magec the sun you love walking through the fields enjoying its light. On one of your walks you meet [From.GetTitledFirstName] who is also dedicating [From.GetHerHis] day to Magec. It is always good to find another devotee.

When you needed an accomplice in a small scheme, [From.GetTitledFirstName] proved to be an unexpected ally. Think what mutual benefits can do to unite two souls! While it was pure business at first, it turns out you have plenty in common, such as your reverence of Set. Now you spend more time conversing than plotting...

You are dancing at the secret rite held in the Samari's honor as your eyes find [From.GetTitledFirstName]'s across the bonfire. For a moment, it is as if the whole world turns silent. The drumming is a distant thunder, yet the rhythmic vibrations run through your body, to your very core...
Tonight, I shall bed [From.GetFirstName] in the name of the Samari.

Lately, you have striven to act in the spirit of Tanit by treating your [From.GetHusbandWife] [From.GetFirstName] with respect and warmth. Slowly it has changed the dynamic of your relationship, and those who are closest to you have noticed it as well.

Your reputation as a devout follower of the Tan Garki has spread across the lands. Many great and seasoned warriors have since traveled to [Root.Capital.GetName] to pledge their allegiance to your cause.

Your reputation as a devout follower of the Tan Dowa has spread across the lands. Many great and seasoned warriors have since traveled to [Root.Capital.GetName] to pledge their allegiance to your cause.
Your reputation as a devout follower of Änti has spread across the lands. Many great and seasoned warriors have since traveled to [Root.Capital.GetName] to pledge their allegiance to your cause.
Your reputation as a devout follower of Gurzil has spread across the lands. Many great and seasoned warriors have since traveled to [Root.Capital.GetName] to pledge their allegiance to your cause.
Glory to the Spirits!
Glory to the great god!

After each hunt you make sure to leave an offering for the Tan Dowa in thanks of their great generosity. They surely must be pleased, for you have noticed that nowadays your arrows find their targets more often than they once did. You have been blessed with strength and a deadly aim.

In your efforts to become more like the good Samari, you have begun treating everyone who crosses your path with more openness and respect. As a result, you have become known for your compassionate ways. Some go as far as calling you "the Voice of the Samari".

In your efforts to become more like the good Tanit, you have begun treating everyone who crosses your path with more openness and respect. As a result, you have become known for your compassionate ways. Some go as far as calling you "the Voice of Tanit".
I am proud to honour the Samari.

Your efforts to make [Root.Capital.GetName] famous for its markets and merchants has paid off. The city is prospering like never before, and more people gather at the shrine of the Babbaku each day. You have inspired many to follow their path.

Your efforts to make the most out of Magec's holy soil has turned you into a true inspiration for your people. Their hard work, in combination with the fair weather which the Goddess has blessed you with, has resulted in the richest harvest in many years. Celebrations in Magec's honor is held in every village.

Following in the footsteps of The Yayan Zanzanna has brought you down many paths you would never otherwise tread. The things one can overhear during such journeys often prove valuable, indeed. Just recently you discovered that [god_plotter.GetTitledFirstName] is plotting against none other than yourself!

Following in the footsteps of Set has brought you down many paths you would never otherwise tread. The things one can overhear during such journeys often prove valuable, indeed. Just recently you discovered that [god_plotter.GetTitledFirstName] is plotting against none other than yourself!

In your search for wisdom in the name of the Yan Riga, you have had more than one epiphany relevant to the welfare of your lands. Spreading that knowledge is not only beneficial to your rule, but also a sacred duty in and of itself.
The spirits' wisdom is a bottomless well. Praised be the bori!

Alkali is a bori from the Yan Riga court, a patron of the dyers and weavers. In a visit to the local market I consider that the best way to honor him is to get myself a new wardrobe of elegant tunics.
Only the finest fabric.
This is too ostentatious for me.

Doguwa is a bori from the Babbaku court, a patron of wrestlers. She is a very complex being made of two halves that not always agree with each other. I am tempted to summon her presence but it could carry a great risk, for I don’t know which half will answer my call.
Dear mother, please come to me!
No, it’s too risky
You feel the spirit take possession of your body and you start to sing her song “With her white cloth she has come”. This is the lovely mother of wrestlers, and she has come to give you her strength.
I feel it already!

You feel the spirit take possession of your body and you start to sing her song “With her white cloth she has come”. However this is not the blessed half of Doguwa, but the wild one of the bush, and has decided to punish you for calling her name.
No, please. My eyes!

Kulita is a bori from the Tan Garki court, a little drummer that marches with the armies. Inspired by him I have experimented with using young boys beating drums to mark the footsteps of my marching troops. This may be a real tactical advantage.
One, two, one, two

As my illness worsens I have tried contacting with the bori spirits. Today my prayers have being answered as I felt how I was possessed by KaiKai, one of the Yayan Zanzanna children of the plague. The lady of the disease took it away, my pain is finally gone.
I must sacrifice two hens in her name.

Ayu the manatee is one of the Tan Dowa wild bori, he drags his victims underwater and drowns them. Kadda the crocodile is a lot more direct, as he breaks them with his jaws. In a recent spirit possession I had the opportunity to choose which of these spirits to call.
The sneaky manatee.
The ferocious crocodile.
Recently I have being practicing a lot of wrestling, as the giant Änti did. It not only has made me feel great but it seems like my new defined abdomen has caught the eye of my [From.GetHusbandWife].
Do you like what you see?
Go away, I have to keep my head on the next match.

Gurzil is a god of war, but one must not forget that he is also a bull. The herders always look for his protection when watching over the cattle. I could make a sacrifice to the horned figure if I want my own lands to have healthy heifers.
The bull shall provide.
I have no money for sacrifices.

The sun shines over all, and it can be both a blessing and a curse. Magec is the radiant sun, and as one of her faithful I always await for her blessing. Lately the sun has certainly favored the crops, the harvest has being plentiful and the profits have being flowing.
Praise the sun!

Strange noises at night, objects moving on their own and terrifying messages written on the ceiling have convinced the entire court that the palace is haunted. I don’t have the heart to admit that it’s just my latest prank, just a game to celebrate Set the lord of chaos.
Maybe I should stop, I am scaring people.
This is so fun. Next, blood on the walls.
